title: Historic Fire Regime Mapping in Northeast United States
text:
This project explores the historic fire regimes across the Northeast US, focusing on understanding how ecological processes, like natural fires, have historically shaped forest structure and species distribution in the Midwest and New England. Using GIS and historical biophysical settings (BPS) data from LANDFIRE, I analyzed past fire frequencies, intensities, and patterns to better understand the natural role of fire in these ecosystems. These insights contribute to efforts in restoring forest resilience, guiding sustainable land management, and adapting to changing environmental conditions.
This project has been instrumental in advancing my technical skills with ArcGIS Pro, a powerful tool widely used in natural resources management. I’ve gained hands-on experience with complex geospatial data analysis, including raster data manipulation and symbology techniques crucial for communicating spatial information. This experience has not only deepened my understanding of ecological processes but also enhanced my ability to apply GIS technology to real-world conservation and land management challenges.
Find more information about LANDFIRE here.
The findings of this study were presented at LANDFIRE Open Office hours on January 29th, 2025. Find a recording here.

title: Experience
text: I have spent multiple seasons conducting field work, in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, in central Northern Idaho, and on the west coast of the United States.

title: Experience
text:
Ashland, Oregon
I worked for the National Park Service’s Klamath Inventory and Monitoring Network (KLMN) based out of Southern Oregon University in Ashland, Oregon. As a vegetation monitoring technician, I collected data on and remonumented long-term monitoring plots. My crew and I navigated to pre-determined plots at Whiskeytown National Recreation Area and Lassen Volcanic National Park in northern California. We collected data on 10002m plots, including-



Species Presence or Absence
Tree and Snag Diameter and Density
Tree Crown Position
Shrub Density
Photo Plots
Tree Seedling Density
Tree and Shrub Mortality
Woody Debris Size and Decay Class





Canopy Height
Fuels
Disturbance
Soil Properties
Elevation
Slope
Aspect
Vegetation Type



This data is used for a variety of projects from the KLMN, including reports on park health and other external publications. We visit plots once every three years, allowing for the monitoring of trends in vegetation composition and vegetation structure and function (including parameters affecting wildlife habitat, fire behavior, and stand dynamics), while still maintaining sensitivity to detect non-linear shifts in vegetation.



Lassen Volcanic National Park and Whiskeytown National Recreation Area

title: Experience
text:
McCall, Idaho
As a Botany Technician Intern with the Payette National Forest, I led and participated in extended field survey trips, working closely with a small team to conduct surveys that support sustainable land management. My role involved conducting threatened and endangered species (TESP) surveys to assess potential impacts of management activities, such as timber sales, hazardous fuel reduction, and road decommissioning projects. I documented understory and overstory plant species, using dichotomous keys and USDA plant codes to build accurate species inventories, and I also collected, prepared, and mounted herbarium specimens for long-term reference.
I contributed to the conservation of sensitive species, including whitebark pine, by gathering critical spatial and statistical data with ArcGIS Field Maps, and I played an active role in developing a standardized data collection protocol for whitebark pine in collaboration with the USFS Region 4 Ecologist and Silviculturist, as well as the Rocky Mountain Research Station. Through this role, I honed my plant identification and field survey skills, while supporting meaningful conservation and habitat management work within the National Forest system.



Payette National Forest

title: Experience
text:
Marquette, Michigan
As an Invasive Species Field Technician for the Marquette County Conservation District, I worked to protect vital ecosystems in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula by managing invasive plant populations across federal, state, and private lands. I conducted extensive surveys, both on foot and by vehicle, covering diverse landscapes like the Hiawatha National Forest, Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore, and Seney National Wildlife Refuge.
Using ArcGIS Field Maps, I mapped invasive species occurrences in the Lake to Lake CISMA area, providing essential data to support local conservation efforts and inform future management strategies. I developed and executed self-directed daily plans, coordinating with field crews to ensure efficient and effective plant removal and habitat restoration.
During my time with the Marquette County Conservation District, I contributed to habitat restoration efforts for the federally threatened Dwarf lake iris (Iris lacustris), reinforcing my commitment to preserving biodiversity. My role also involved continual learning and professional development, including attending regional CISMA training for the identification of Himalayan Balsam and European Frog Bit, as well as the 2023 Michigan Invasive Species Coalition summer field trip hosted by Lake to Lake CISMA.



Marquette County Conservation District
